newsitem.title: HUNGARY: CROATIA AIRLINES CARGO TRADE UP 10.3 PCT JAN-MAY.
newsitem.headline: CROATIA AIRLINES CARGO TRADE UP 10.3 PCT JAN-MAY.

text.p: Croatia's national airline
Croatia Airlines DD said its cargo trade in the
January-to-May period increased 10.3 percent in 1996 from 1995.
CARGO TRADE (in tonnes) JAN-MAY 96 JAN-MAY 95 PCT CHANGE
TOTAL EXPORTS 598.5 616.3 -2.9
TOTAL IMPORTS 963.8 800.3 +20.4
TRADE BALANCE -365.3 -184.0 -
NOTE - Cargo includes freight and mail. In the trade
balance, negative numbers indicate export deficits.
Croatia Airlines expects its cargo trade to total 4,925
tonnes in 1996. Its cargo trade totalled 4,603 tonnes in 1995,
4,431 tonnes in 1994, 3,811 tonnes in 1993, 1,956 tonnes in
1992 and 94 tonnes in 1991.
Currently the airline carries cargo mainly on scheduled
flights, though small volumes travel by trucks. It flies 26
international scheduled destinations. Important cargo routes
include Amsterdam, Brussels, Frankfurt, London and Skopje.
The airline, which employs approximately 630 people, was
formed in 1989 as Zagreb Airlines DD. It has operated under
its current name since 1990.
Its airplane fleet includes six Boeing B737-200s and three
Aerospatiale ATR 42s. The airline plans to add as many as 12
airplanes to its fleet by 2002, according to media reports. The
current fleet would be sold or modernised for charter flights.
Croatia Airlines is owned 27.1 percent by Croatia's
state-owned oil company INA, 14.2 percent by Airport
Zagreb, 9.5 percent by the Croatian Privatisation Fund and
49.2 percent by various shareholders, including Jadranski
Naftovod DD or JANAF (operator of the Adriatic oil pipeline),
Croatia's state-owned post and telecommunications operator
and the Croatian Lottery.
-- Ryan Tutak, Budapest newsroom (36 1) 266 2410
